title: How to Fix a Broken Car Horn

steps.headline: Make sure your car is turned off.
steps.description: Before you begin working in the fuse box of your car, turn the engine off and take the keys out of the ignition. Electricity running through the fuses could potentially shock or electrocute you, so it’s important that you make sure the car’s battery isn’t active.

steps.headline: Look under the hood or dashboard of your car to find the fuse box.
steps.description: Most cars have at least 2 fuse boxes, but the fuse for your car’s horn is likely under the hood or beneath the dashboard near the steering wheel. Look for a black box with a removable lid that contains the individual fuses. The fuse box in the dashboard may require you to remove a panel so you can access it. Look for a small handle on the dashboard that you can pull to open the panel. Check the owner’s manual for the locations of the fuse boxes. If you don’t have the owner’s manual, look up the fuse box location for your car’s make and model online. It’s possible your car’s fuse box with the horn fuse is located in the glove compartment.

steps.headline: Locate the fuse for the horn in the diagram on the lid of the fuse box.
steps.description: On the inside of the lid of the fuse box is a diagram that labels the fuses. Look for the horn fuse on the diagram and match it to the corresponding fuse in the box. The diagram may contain a list that corresponds with a letter and number on the fuse. For example, it may say that the horn fuse is M3. Look in the fuse box for the fuse labeled M3 to identify the horn fuse.

steps.headline: Use a pair of needle-nose pliers to remove the fuse.
steps.description: Car fuses are small and it can be difficult to get a good grip on them with your fingers. Use a pair of needle-nose pliers to grab hold of the top of the fuse and pull it straight out of the fuse box. Don’t wiggle or bend the fuse or you could break off a piece in the fuse box that will difficult to remove.Tip: If you don’t have needle-nosed pliers, use a pair of tweezers to pull out the fuse.

steps.headline: Check the fuse for a broken filament inside of it.
steps.description: Hold the fuse up to the light and look for a thin wire connecting the 2 sides of the fuse. If the wire is broken or a section of it has burned away, then the fuse is bad. If the wire between the 2 sides is still whole, then the fuse is good and can be reinstalled in the box. If the plastic on the fuse looks smokey or cracked, then the fuse is blown. A functioning fuse means that the problem could be the horn relay or horn itself, which needs to be replaced. Sometimes you can’t tell that a fuse is bad just by looking at it. Try replacing the fuse anyway if your horn isn’t working. If the fuse isn’t damaged or blown, replace it back into the slot you removed it from.

steps.headline: Install a new fuse that matches the blown one into the fuse box.
steps.description: If the fuse is blown, replacing it is an easy fix. Insert a fuse with the same amperage into the slot for the horn fuse. Make sure it’s fully inserted, then close the lid of the fuse box, and test the horn to see if it’s working. The diagram on the inside of the fuse box lid should list the amperage of the fuse so you can find the correct replacement fuse. Take the blown fuse to an auto supply store to make sure you get a fuse with the same amperage as a replacement. The fuse should snap into place in the fuse box, but don’t try to force or jam it in or you could damage the box or the fuse. Wiggle the fuse box lid with your hands to make sure it’s secure so it doesn’t fall off when you’re driving.

methods.name: Checking the Horn Relay and Connections

steps.headline: Turn off the engine before you work on the car.
steps.description: When the car is turned on, electricity flows to the horn. To prevent accidentally shocking or electrocuting yourself, turn off the car’s engine and take the keys out of the ignition.

steps.headline: Make sure the wires are correctly connected to the horn.
steps.description: Your car’s horn draws power from the battery via 2 wires. Locate your horn behind the front grill—it's a small metal disk with 2 cables connected to it. Then, check the wires to make sure they’re connected to the horn. Look up a diagram online or refer to your owner's manual if you have trouble locating the horn. If the wires are loose or aren’t connected, reconnect them to the horn by pushing them back into their connections and then test it by pressing on the steering wheel.

steps.headline: Find the horn relay in the fuse box under the hood.
steps.description: Pop the hood of your car and look for the fuse box. Take off the lid and inspect the fuses and relays. The relays look like larger fuses. On the inside of the cover of the fuse box, there’s a diagram that labels all of the fuses and relays in the box. Look for the fuse relay on the diagram and then find where it’s plugged into the fuse box. If you can’t find the fuse box, check the owner’s manual for its location or look up your car’s make and model online to find the box.

steps.headline: Replace the horn relay with a matching relay.
steps.description: Pull the relay straight out of the fuse box. Plug in a new relay into the same slot and close the lid of the fuse box. You won’t be able to tell if the relay is blown by looking at it. Make sure you replace the relay with one that has the same amperage.Tip: Bring the relay you remove to an auto supply store so you can get a new one that is the same amperage.

steps.headline: Test the horn by pressing the steering wheel.
steps.description: After you’ve installed the new relay, press the horn button on the steering wheel. The horn should work properly. If the horn doesn’t make a sound after you’ve checked the wires and replaced the relay, you may need to replace the horn itself.

steps.headline: Make sure the car’s engine is turned off.
steps.description: The electricity running through the engine powers the horn and could potentially shock or electrocute you. Before you start working on the horn, make sure the engine is off and the keys are out of the ignition.

steps.headline: Remove the grill from the front of the car.
steps.description: The horn of your car is located behind the front grill. In order to access it so you can replace it, you need to remove the grill. Every car will have a slightly different grill that can usually be removed by disengaging the clips or brackets that are holding it on. Wedge a screwdriver into the crease between the grill and the hood and apply pressure to pry the grill off. It may be easier to remove your grill by opening the hood so you can push it from the inside. Some cars may have screws that need to be removed to take the grill off.

steps.headline: Locate the horn behind the grill.
steps.description: Your car’s horn will look like a small metal disk with 2 cables connected to it. After you remove the grill, look for the horn mounted on the screen that was behind the grill on the front of the car. The horn may to the left or right of the front screen.

steps.headline: Detach the cables on the old horn.
steps.description: Look for 2 small black wires plugged into 2 ports on the backside of the horn. Gently pull the cables to unplug them and disconnect power from the horn. The cables should hang in place after you unplug them. Don’t try to pull out the cables or allow them to fall further back into the engine if they’re loose.

steps.headline: Unscrew the connections around the horn.
steps.description: The horn will have 1 or more screws or bolts connecting it to the car. Unscrew the bolts or screws and remove the old horn. Make sure you don’t lose the screws or bolts so you can replace them!

steps.headline: Purchase a new horn that is compatible with your car.
steps.description: Most car horns can be installed on any vehicle, but before you buy one, make sure it will work on your car. Check the packaging on the horn to see if it’s compatible with your car. Bring your old horn to an auto supply store to get a similar one. Check the details of the horn on the packaging or read the product information if you’re ordering it online to make sure it’s compatible.

steps.headline: Install the new horn to the connections.
steps.description: Place the new horn where the old horn was held in place. Screw in the bolts or screws to secure it firmly. Don’t tighten so hard that you risk cracking the connections. Make sure the horn is secure by wiggling it with your hands so it doesn’t rattle or bounce around while you’re driving.Tip: Check the packaging on the horn set for any specific installation instructions.

steps.headline: Insert the wires into the newly installed horn and test it.
steps.description: Once the horn is secure, plug each of the wires into the ports on the backside of the horn. Insert the 2 wires into the ports the same way they were connected to the old horn. After the wires are attached, try pressing the horn to test it and make sure it’s working properly. The wires should fit securely into place.

steps.headline: Replace the grill on the front of the car.
steps.description: When you’ve finished installing the new horn, put your grill back on to complete the job. Click it back into place if it uses brackets or screw the grill back on to its original position. Try wiggling the grill with your hand to make sure it’s secure before you drive your car.
